Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my stepmother’s voice warm as she asked, “Will you come with us to the lake this Saturday? Your brother’s been looking forward to it.” My stepbrother grinned at me, hope shining in his eyes. I nodded, feeling the familiar tug of family expectation—being present, sharing laughter, making memories. But as I sipped my tea, my phone buzzed with a message from Sister Agnes: “We’re holding a special healing service for Sister Maria on Saturday. Your presence would mean a lot.” My heart clenched. The community needed me, too. I was expected to be there, to pray, to offer comfort and faith. The two worlds pressed in on me, each demanding my presence, each holding a piece of my loyalty. I wanted to be the sister my family needed, but also the nun my community relied on. The weight of choosing between them settled heavy in my chest, and I stared at my hands, torn and uncertain, as the voices of both families echoed in my mind.
